document.docAuthor: Brescovit, Antonio D. & Santos, Adalberto J.
document.masterDocTitle: The spider genus Kukulcania in South America (Araneae: Filistatidae): a redescription of K. brevipes (Keyserling) and new records of K. hibernalis (Hentz)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The spider genus Kukulcania in South America (Araneae: Filistatidae): a redescription of K. brevipes (Keyserling) and new records of K. hibernalis (Hentz)

Departamento de Zoologia, Instituto de Ciências Biológicas, Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais, Av. Antonio Carlos, 6627. Belo Horizonte, MG, Brazil. CEP 31270 - 901. E-mail: oxyopes @ yahoo. com

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Kukulcania hibernalis : Lehtinen, 1967: 242
, fig. 19. Platnick (2013 – full synonymic list).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis .
Males of
Kukulcania hibernalis
can be distinguished from those of
K. brevipes
by the less spiny venter of tibiae of palp and leg I ( Figs. 1D , 2D ), by the cymbium without modified distal setae and the stout, coiled embolus ( Figs. 1 EF). Females can be recognized by the medially positioned spermathecae ( Fig. 3B , see also Ramírez & Grismado 1997 : fig. 110).

Description .
For morphological remarks and illustrations of male and female, see Ramírez & Grismado (1997: 348 , figs 1, 4, 7, 107–111) and Ramírez & Grismado (2008: 80 , figs 1, 3, 6, 10, 14). For comparison with
K. brevipes
, we present herein images of the male palp and leg I ( Figs. 1E–F , 2D ), and female palp, leg I and internal genitalia ( Figs. 2 EF, 3B).

Distribution .
Widely distributed in the New World, particularly in synanthropic conditions. In South America known from Argentina ( Ramírez & Grismado 1997 , 2008 ), Bolivia , southeastern and southern Brazil (
Brescovit et al. 2011
,
Buckup et al. 2010
), Chile ( Taucare-Ríos 2010 ), Colombia ( Flórez & Sánchez 1997 ), Paraguay ( Kochalka 1996 ), Uruguay ( Capocasale 1990 ) and Venezuela ( Fig. 9 ).
